Procedural_Stage: Appeal from Trade-marks Opposition Board decision
Evidence_Assessment: Co-existence of 'London' marks in similar goods categories; differences in appearance, sound, and meaning of the marks
Burden_of_Proof: On opponent (London Drugs) to demonstrate confusion
Legal_Rule: Confusion exists if marks resemble in appearance, sound, or suggested ideas and could mislead consumers about origin
Grounds_for_Claim: Potential consumer confusion due to similarity with existing LONDON DRUGS trademarks
Key_Evidence_Considered: Distinctiveness of the term 'London'; duration and nature of use; nature of goods/services; degree of resemblance between marks
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law under the Trade-marks Act
Applicant_Challenge: International Clothiers' application for SMITH & BARNES LONDON
Court_Result: Upheld Boardâ€™s decision, dismissed appeal with costs
Defendant_Response: Argued that 'London' is a geographic term lacking distinctiveness; minimal resemblance to LONDON DRUGS
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of prior registrations; reputation evidence; comparative visual and phonetic analysis
Remedy_Requested: Opposition to registration of SMITH & BARNES LONDON
Remedy_Sought: Prevent registration of the mark SMITH & BARNES LONDON
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative opposition followed by judicial appeal
Legal_Provision: Section 56 of the Trade-marks Act (appeal to Federal Court)
Authority: Trade-marks Opposition Board; Federal Court of Canada
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Allegation of confusing similarity under Section 6(5)
Applicable_Process: Opposition proceeding under the Trade-marks Regulations
Outcome_of_Review: No error in Board's assessment; decision upheld
